titleStmt.title: Temperature dependence of elastic moduli in a refractory HfNbTaTiZr high-entropy alloy

affiliation.orgName: D epartement de Physique et M ecanique des Mat eriaux

analytic.title: Temperature dependence of elastic moduli in a refractory HfNbTaTiZr high-entropy alloy

biblStruct.note: Received 16 April 2019 Received in revised form 23 May 2019 Accepted 28 May 2019

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: High entropy alloys TiZrNbHfTa Microstructure Texture Elastic constants

div.p: The equiatomic HfNbTaTiZr solid solution is currently regarded as a model disordered body-centered cubic high-entropy alloy. Therefore, the temperature dependence of its elastic moduli is of prime importance to improve our understanding of the mechanical properties of this refractory alloy. In this study, the alloy was found to be single phase, fully recrystallized with a slight texture along the normal direction after thermomechanical processing at room temperature. Elastic moduli were determined over the temperature range [293 K-1100 K].

div.head: Introduction
div.p: As alloys remain in high demand for advanced structural applications, increasing efforts have been carried out to explore new high-entropy alloys containing high concentrations of refractory elements with high melting points [1e4]. Senkov et al. [1] first discovered the equiatomic NbMoTaW and NbMoTaVW refractory high-entropy alloys (RHEAs) which form fully disordered body centered cubic (BCC) solid solutions and are able to retain high strength up to 1600 K. In particular, these materials were shown to have higher yield strengths above 873 K than conventional superalloys. To further optimize these alloys for possible aerospace applications, Senkov et al. [5] replaced heavy elements such as W and Mo by lighter ones (Ti and Zr) in order to reduce the alloy density. As a result, a new HfNbTaTiZr RHEA was designed with a reduced density of ~9.9 g/cm 3 and despite its high melting point, different groups could also successfully produce this RHEA using different processing techniques such as arc melting [6], spark plasma sintering [7], and laser metal deposition [8,9]. More importantly, this alloy was found to have an impressive combination of strength and ductility at room temperature for a BCC alloy [10]. Because of its excellent malleability, cast HfNbTaTiZr can be processed by rolling [10,11] and high-pressure torsion [12] at room temperature followed by recrystallization heat treatments. Due to these features, HfNbTaTiZr has received an increasing interest in the material science community and is currently one of the most understood BCC RHEA so far regarding phase stability [12e16], mechanical properties and deformation mechanisms [11,17e23]. Regarding the mechanical properties, Senkov et al. [17] were the first to report the effect of temperature on compression behavior of as-cast HfNbTa-TiZr. When deformed at a strain rate of 10 À3 s À1 between 296 K and 1473 K, the yield strength of HfNbTaTiZr was found to decrease monotonically with increasing temperature. As the yield strength of the alloy should be directly proportional to its shear modulus (i.e., the Peierls stress and the strength of solute pinning depends linearly on shear modulus), it is therefore not clear to which extent its elastic softening with increasing temperature contributes to the temperature dependence of strength. Moreover, elastic moduli are required to determine other mechanical properties, e.g., fracture toughness and work hardening rate. Therefore, the main objective of the present paper is to document the temperature dependence of elastic moduli.

To date few attempts have been carried out in the literature to determine the elastic properties of HfNbTaTiZr [24e26]. Fazakas et al. [24] calculated the elastic constants of HfNbTaTiZr alloys using ab initio alloy theory. More recently, Dirras et al. [26] measured the elastic moduli in HfNbTaTiZr using ultrasound measurements at 293 K. At this point, it is worth mentioning that these measurements were performed in an as-cast alloy with a very large grain size distribution (20 mm -600 mm). For this reason, the authors could not ensure that they probed a single large grain or an assembly of small grains. Therefore the elastic parameters reported by Dirras et al. [26] may not be representative of a polycrystal with random grain orientations and their assumption of an elastically isotropic material for the calculation of polycrystalline parameters may not be valid. A comparison of the elastic parameters measured by Dirras et al. [26] with those calculated by Fazakas et al. [24] reveals a large discrepancy on several parameters, such as ~56% difference regarding the c 44 elastic constant. Therefore, further experimental and theoretical works are still needed to characterize the elastic properties of the HfNbTaTiZr RHEA.

In the present study, the HfNbTaTiZr RHEA was produced by arcmelting and was subsequently homogenized, cold-rolled at room temperature, and recrystallized. This process yielded a single-phase disordered BCC alloy with grains slightly smaller along the normal direction of the rolled sheets (aspect ratio of ~1.3) and a mean grain size of ~70 mm. The elastic moduli of this HfNbTaTiZr RHEA were measured between 293 K and 1100 K using a resonance frequency technique.

div.head: Material processing
div.p: The HfNbTaTiZr material has been prepared by arc melting under argon atmosphere starting from pure metals (purity ! 99.95 wt %). The complete procedure has been already reported elsewhere [6] and could be summarized through the three following steps. First, two master alloys (Hf-Ti-Zr and Nb-Ta) were melted twice separately and then mixed together. Second, chemical homogenization was ensured by electromagnetic stirring using highfrequency induction technique in a copper crucible under helium partial pressure. Third, the alloy was arc melted in a water-cooled and rectangular shaped copper mold (60 mm long, 10 mm wide, and 10 mm height) where it solidified. Fully recrystallized microstructure was obtained after thermo-mechanical treatment consisting of an ~80% thickness reduction of the cast ingot by cold rolling followed by an annealing at 1373 K during 5 h under a helium stream. In the framework of the present study, two ingots of a near-equiatomic HfNbTaTiZr composition were prepared (B23 and B24).

div.head: Microstructure and chemical composition
div.p: Standard polishing methods using SiC papers and oxide suspensions (OPS) were carried out for microstructural investigations of the refractory HEA after thermo-mechanical processing. A Zeiss Merlin scanning electron microscope (SEM) operated at 20 kV, 8.0 nA and equipped with an electron backscattered diffraction (EBSD) camera from the Oxford company was used to analyze the alloy texture as well as its grain size. Alloy composition was determined by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) at 20 kV and 1.0 nA. At the exception of Ti for which the characteristic Ka Xrays were used, quantification of Hf, Nb, Ta and Zr was made considering the characteristic La X-rays. The concentration of interstitial elements was determined after the last annealing heat treatment at a commercial laboratory (Bureau Veritas, Paris, France) by combustion infrared absorption (carbon) and inert gaz fusion (nitrogen and oxygen) methods.

div.head: Elastic moduli
div.p: The Young's modulus as well as the shear modulus of the recrystallized RHEA were measured between room temperature and 1100 K following the ASTM E1876 standard test method [27]. For this purpose, specimens with their gauge length parallel to the rolling direction of the sheets were electric discharge machined and polished with SiC papers from 14 mm to 4 mm. Beams with dimensions of 30 Â 5 Â 1.2 mm 3 were elastically bent while plates with dimensions of 30 Â 10 Â 1.2 mm 3 were elastically loaded in torsion using an oscillating excitation with strain amplitudes smaller than 10 À6 [28] under high vacuum (10 À4 Pa) at a heating rate of 2 K/min. A network analyzer was used to determine resonant excitation frequencies for the two specimen geometries (beams and plates) by sweeping the excitation frequency in the kHz frequency range. At this stage, it is worth recalling that thermal dilatation is known to affect the determination of elastic moduli. However for our sample geometry, it was shown that the maximum deviation is ~1.5% at 1000 K [29]. As this deviation is very small, the effect of thermal dilatation on elastic moduli was neglected in the present study. The damping coefficient Q À1 ¼ DF/F was determined by measuring the width of the resonance peak DF at À3 dB [30].
Physically, the damping coefficient represents the energy loss per cycle divided by twice the total vibrational energy of the system.
From the torsional resonance frequency F T , the shear modulus G of the plates was calculated using [31]:
div.formula: G ¼ r F 2 T h 2 T þ e 2 T l 2 T 1 À eT ffiffi ffi 3 p hT ! e 2 T ;(1)
div.p: where e T , h T , and l T are the plate thickness, width, and gauge length, respectively, and r represents the density of the alloy with a value of 9.9 g/cm 3 ± 0.1 g/cm 3 . Similarly, the Young's modulus E of the beams was determined using bending resonance frequency F B using:
div.formula: E ¼ 0:9464 r F 2 B l 4 B e 2 B U e B l B ; n ; (2
div.p: where n is Poisson's ratio, e B and l B are the beam thickness and gauge length, respectively. For our sample geometry (e B /l B ¼ 1.2/ 30), the correcting factor U in Eq. ( 2) is close to 1 and is nearly independent of n.

div.head: Composition and microstructure
div.p: The chemical compositions of specimens B23 and B24 were determined by EDX at 15 different locations on longitudinal and cross-sections. The experimental scatter between the results obtained for each sample does not exceed 0.2 at. % which is below the experimental error of 0.5 at.% for EDX. Therefore our processing method yields chemically homogeneous sheets which average compositions are very close to the targeted equiatomic composition, see Table 1. Moreover, both specimens exhibit similar impurity levels, i.e. ~0.07 at.% C, 0.10 at.% N and 0.27 at.% O for the B23 ingot.

The microstructure and texture of the B23 sheet were analysed by EBSD using a longitudinal section (see schematic drawing in Fig. 1a) as well as a cross-section (Fig. 1b). A fully recrystallized microstructure is achieved after cold rolling followed by annealing at 1373 K for 5 h as shown in Fig. 1. The grains are equiaxed in the (RD,TD) plane and the average grain size is about 80 mm (see grain orientation maps in Fig. 1a). A slight texture is evidenced after coldrolling and subsequent recrystallization with <111> directions of the grains parallel to the normal direction of the sheet (g-fiber) and <110> along the rolling one (a-fiber), see the three inverse pole figures in Fig. 1a. The texture found in the equiatomic HfNbTaTiZr is in good agreement with that found in BCC metals and alloys [32,33].

As the investigation of a longitudinal section could miss some unrecrystallized regions, e.g. Ref. [34], a cross-section highlighted with a red (TD,ND) plane in the schematic of Fig. 1b was investigated to check whether the sheet is fully recrystallized throughout its thickness. In the cross-section plane which spans the whole thickness of the cold rolled and annealed sheet, the microstructure was found to be fully recrystallized and grains appeared somewhat shorter in the ND direction. The mean grain size determined with this cross-section is smaller and is ~60 mm. At this stage it worth mentioning that this slight anisotropic shape of the grains does not have any effect on the measured elastic properties.

div.head: Elastic properties of the HfNbTaTiZr alloy
div.p: The elastic moduli determined as a function of temperature are shown in Fig. 2 where the experimental uncertainties, determined using two independent experiments, are indicated by the thickness of the black lines in Fig. 2. Young's modulus (E ¼ 90 GPa ± 1 GPa) and shear modulus (G ¼ 35.8 GPa ± 0.2 GPa) determined at room temperature are respectively 12% and 26% larger than those reported by Dirras et al. [26] and 18% and 7% lower than those calculated by Fazakas et al. [24], see Table 2. As shown in Fig. 1, the HfNbTaTiZr RHEA investigated in the presented study is nearly untextured. Considering the current RHEA with elastic isotropic theory, its bulk modulus B and Poisson's ratio n can be calculated using the following expressions:
div.formula: B ¼ E G 3 ð3 G À EÞ ;(3)
n ¼ À 1 þ E 2 G (4
div.p: Using Eqs. ( 3) and ( 4), the values of B and n at room temperature are 62 ± 6 GPa and 0.26 ± 0.02, respectively. The magnitude of the elastic moduli E and G decreases with increasing temperature and the slopes of the E(T) and G(T) curves are becoming more negative at higher temperatures (see Fig. 2). This temperature dependence of the elastic moduli is typical of other metallic materials such as pure metals [35,36], Fe-based [37] Table 1 Chemical compositions (in at. %) of the two equiatomic HfNbTaTiZr high-entropy alloys labelled B23 and B24. Semi-quantitative EDX analysis of Hf, Nb, Ta, Ti and Zr contents and impurity levels determined by combustion infrared absorption method for carbon and inert gaz fusion technique for nitrogen and oxygen. and Ni-based alloys [38], intermetallics [39,40], quasicrystals [41,42] as well as face-centered cubic high and medium entropy alloys [29,43,44] where no phase transformation or magnetic transition happens in the studied temperature range [35,45,46]. The temperature dependencies of the Young's and shear moduli can be fitted to the empirical equation proposed by Varshni [47] and are given by

div.head: Ingot
div.formula: EðTÞ ¼ E 0 À s E e t E T À 1 ; (5
GðTÞ ¼ G 0 À s G e t G T À 1 ; (6
div.p: where E 0 and G 0 are the elastic moduli at 0 K, and s E , s G , t E and t G are constants. Experimental E and G values (black lines in Fig. 2) were fitted to Eqs. ( 5) and ( 6), respectively, using the method of least squares (red lines). Excellent agreements between the experimental elastic moduli and the fitted curves were obtained over the investigated temperature range using the fitting parameters shown in Fig. 2 and listed Table 2. The temperature dependence of the shear modulus shown in Fig. 2 is relatively weak. The shear modulus decreases by ~12% from ~36 GPa at 293 K to ~31 GPa at 1073 K. Therefore, the much larger decrease of the compressive yield strength (~70%) reported by Senkov et al. [17] in the same temperature range, cannot be only attributed to softening of the shear modulus; it rather reflects thermally-activated processes. As thermal activation only concerns coherent fluctuations of a very small number of atoms, it is therefore likely that plastic flow is controlled by very local events in HfNbTaTiZr. This is consistent with apparent and effective activation volumes between 30 b 3 and 50 b 3 which were reported in the literature [11,18].

div.head: Damping behavior
div.p: The HfNbTaTiZr RHEA exhibits a slight discontinuity in its E(T) curve between 700 K and 950 K. To make this discontinuity more visible, this curve (black line, left y-axis) is magnified and the corresponding damping Q À1 curve (blue line, right y-axis) is presented in Fig. 3. Also shown in Fig. 3 is a Varshni fit (red line) for which the temperature range [700 K-950 K] was ignored to again better highlight the discontinuity. The damping curve (blue line) shows an increase between 700 and 950 K, which is superimposed onto a high temperature-dependent background. The latter is commonly attributed to the viscoelastic motion of extended defects under stress (dislocations and grain boundaries) [30] while the former could be either rationalized by the presence of C, N, and O interstitials or the decomposition of the HfNbTaTiZr disordered solid solution into NbTa-and ZrHf-rich phases [12,16] which occurs at high temperatures. To investigate the second possibility, the elastic moduli were determined a second time at 300 K after the first set of measurements at high temperatures. As the elastic moduli were found to be identical to those determined prior to the first thermal cycle, it can therefore be concluded that precipitation (if any) does not affect the reported elastic moduli and that the discontinuity observed in Fig. 3 is not due to the precipitation of secondary phases. It is well known that interstitials in BCC metals occupy some of the available octahedral sites, distort the surrounding crystal lattice and form elastic dipoles. In the unloaded state, the interstitials are randomly distributed over the octahedral sites. In contrast, under a tensile stress some of the sites are stretched and preferentially occupied by interstitials while the others are compressed through the Poisson effect and are therefore unfavorable. Under an oscillating tension/compression stress, an interstitial Shear (G), Young's (E), bulk (B) moduli (in GPa), and Poisson's ratio (n) determined at room temperature. Also listed are Young's and shear moduli parameters (E 0 , s E , T E and G 0 , s G , T G ) obtained by fitting Eqs. ( 5) and ( 6) to the experimental data shown in Fig. 2. For comparison, the parameters reported in Refs. [24,26] placed on a favorable octahedral site under tension is forced to diffuse toward an adjacent octahedral site under compression to minimize its energy (if the temperature is high enough to allow diffusion). As the rearrangement of interstitials in the BCC lattice is diffusion controlled, the process does not occur instantaneously, but takes place through a relaxation process which gives rise to a thermally activated damping peak known as a Snoek type relaxation peak [30,48]. Indeed at low temperatures/high frequencies, the diffusion of interstitials is too slow compared to the excitation frequency to give rise to a relaxation phenomenon. At high temperatures/low frequencies, interstitial diffusion is fast compared to the excitation frequency and again no relaxation behavior can be detected. In contrast, in a well-defined temperature/frequency range, a damping relaxation peak can be observed. Weller has compiled the activation parameters of such damping peak for C, N, and O interstitials in various BCC metals [49]. Using these parameters with an Arrhenius type of law, temperatures at which these interstitials should give rise to a damping peak in Ta and Nb are calculated for an excitation frequency of 7 kHz (similar to our experimental excitation frequency range). These temperatures are given in Table 3 and are found to be between 650 K and 970 K which are consistent with the temperature range [700 Ke950 K] of the observed damping phenomenon in HfNbTaTiZr. Therefore it is likely that the apparent damping peak in Fig. 3 corresponds to the overlap of three relaxation peaks of Snoek type corresponding to C, N, and O interstitials. However, further work on doped specimens as well as prestrained polycrystals is required to investigate their respective role on the observed anelastic effects in the HfNbTaTiZr RHEA.

div.head: Comparison with elemental constituents
div.p: In Fig. 4, the temperature dependence of the elastic moduli E and G for the BCC RHEA investigated in the present study is compared to those for the elemental constituents Hf, Nb, Ta, Ti and Zr (with a BCC structure) reported in the literature (Table 4). At this stage, it is important to point out that except for Nb and Ta which form a stable BCC phase from room temperature up to their respective melting points, Hf, Ti, and Zr are HCP at room temperature and BCC above 1155 K, 2128 K, and 2015 K [50,51], respectively (see arrows in Fig. 4). Different types of elastic moduli are compiled in Fig. 4. Full lines are experimental data obtained for polycrystalline Ta [35,36,52], Nb [52], and the HfNbTaTiZr (this study) measured by resonance frequency techniques. Empty symbols at 0 K represent single crystalline data obtained using first principle calculations or density functional theory [51,53e55] which were converted to polycrystalline elastic moduli using the Voigt-Reuss-Hill averaging method [56]. Similarly, experimental data for single crystalline Ta [57,58], Nb [59], and Ti [60,61] were converted to polycrystalline elastic moduli, see blue and pink dashed lines as well as the red data points at 1273 K, respectively. The green and purple data points correspond also to single crystalline data obtained by phonon dispersion for Zr [62] and Hf [63] which were converted to polycrystalline elastic moduli. From the temperature dependence of the elastic moduli shown in Fig. 4, the BCC HfNbTaTiZr alloy and the pure BCC metals can be divided into three groups: (i) Hf, Ti, and Zr show negative values of E and G which reflect the fact that these elements do not form a stable BCC structure at low temperatures (the elastic constant (c 11 -c 12 )/ 2 is negative for Hf, Ti, and Zr). The elastic moduli then increase, become positive and reach a steady state with increasing temperature. For example, Ogi et al. [64] reported that the elastic moduli of BCC Ti are nearly temperature independent above the HCP to BCC phase transformation temperature. The authors attributed this behavior to the compensation of the usual temperature-induced softening by the structural stabilization of the BCC phase with increasing temperature, which increases its stiffness. These results are consistent with those obtained for pure BCC Zr by Heiming et al. [62] who calculated the elastic constants at 1188 K, 1483 K, and 1888 K from the force constants according to the high temperature phonon dispersion, see green data points in Fig. 4. Similar experiments were performed by Trampenau et al. [63] who determined the elastic constants of BCC Hf at 2073 K, see purple data point. (ii) Nb exhibits an unusual temperature behavior. Instead of the classical temperature-induced softening due to anharmonic effects, the elastic moduli show a broad minimum at ~550 K and a broad maximum near ~1750 K but overall the elastic moduli remain relatively constant over the whole temperature range. This singular behavior may be related to the displacement of the Fermi surface during elastic strain and the subsequent transfer of electron across Brillouin-zone boundaries [55]. (iii) Ta and the RHEA both exhibit the usual temperature-induced softening. Therefore, the temperature dependence of the elastic moduli of the HfNbTaTiZr RHEA does not appear to be anomalous.

div.head: Shear modulus mismatch and its contribution to substitutional solid solution strengthening
div.p: It is well known that a peculiarity of BCC metals and alloys is that their screw dislocations have a non-planar extended core that require high stresses (high Peierls stress) to glide by a double-kink mechanism that is thermally activated [65]. At high temperatures, thermal fluctuations may be strong enough such that the screw dislocations do not feel the Peierls potential resulting in an athermal regime where the yield stress is independent of temperature [65]. In this latter athermal regime, the yield stress is mainly affected by solid-solution strengthening. According to the seminal publications of Fleischer and Labusch for dilute and concentrated binary alloys [66e69] as well as more recent theories [70] and correlations [71,72], solid solution strengthening results from the elastic interaction between the stress fields surrounding dislocations and solute atoms. In the frame of isotropic elasticity, the solute atoms only interact with edge dislocations however when anisotropic elasticity is considered, screw dislocations also interact to some extent with solute atoms. In high-entropy alloys, each element is considered as a solute embedded in an effective matrix which exhibits the average properties of the alloy (average lattice parameter and average shear modulus) [70]. Two components contribute to solid solution strengthening, namely, the shear modulus mismatch and the size misfit between a specific atom in the alloy and the matrix. From the results reported in the present study as well as those taken from the literature for the elemental constituents (see Fig. 4), the shear modulus mismatch in HfNbTa-TiZr can be evaluated. Ta is found to have the largest shear modulus mismatch compared to the RHEA followed by Zr, Ti and Hf, while Nb exhibits roughly the same shear modulus as the RHEA. Therefore, if it is assumed that the shear modulus mismatch strongly contributes to the strength of the HfNbTaTiZr RHEA, hardening effects are then mainly due to the mismatch between the modulus of Ta atoms and that of the matrix (alloy).

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: An equiatomic HfNbTaTiZr high-entropy alloy was produced by arc-melting. The cast ingots were homogenized, cold rolled, and recrystallized at 1373 K for 5 h. After recrystallization, the alloy was found to be a single-phase BCC solid solution with equiaxed grains and a nearly random texture. Its elastic moduli were determined as a function of temperature. From the results obtained in the present study, the following conclusions can be drawn:

(1) No discontinuities were detected in the curves of the elastic moduli versus temperature upon heating from 293 K to 1100 K, indicating that the alloy did not undergo any obvious bulk phase transformation in this temperature range and under our experimental conditions; (2) At room temperature (300 K), the elastic moduli of the polycrystalline HfNbTaTiZr RHEA are: G ¼ 35.8 GPa, E ¼ 90 GPa, B ¼ 62 GPa, and n ¼ 0.26;

(3) The influence of temperature on shear and Young's moduli between 300 K and 1100 K can be quantitatively described by the following expressions: G ¼ 36.2e5.6/(e 845/T -1) and E ¼ 90.8e14.0/(e 860/T -1); (4) The shear modulus is found to weakly decrease from ~36 GPa at 300 K to ~31 GPa at 1073 K. It can therefore be ruled out that the strong temperature dependence of the yield strength originates from the softening of the shear modulus with increasing temperature. (5) A modulus defect associated with a damping relaxation peak was detected between 700 K and 950 K. This effect may be related to the presence of interstitial atoms. (6) A comparison of the elastic moduli of the HfNbTaTiZr alloy to those of its elemental constituents reveals that Ta exhibits the largest shear modulus mismatch (Ta is two times stiffer than the alloy) followed by Ti, Zr, and Hf (between 20% and 50% less stiff than the alloy). Nb has roughly the same shear modulus as the refractory high-entropy alloy. [62]

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 1. Microstructure and texture of the recrystallized HfNbTaTiZr sheet (B23 sample) determined by EBSD. (a) Three colored grain orientation maps (top) and three inverse pole figures (bottom right) corresponding to the rolling, (RD), transverse (TD), and normal (ND) directions. The schematic at the bottom left represents the sheet, its coordinate system and the green longitudinal section highlights the region from where the EBSD data were recorded. Scanned area: ~4 mm 2 . Step size: 1.5 mm. (b) Drawing showing a red cross-section spanning the whole thickness of the sheet. From this (TD,ND) plane, three grain orientation maps were obtained. Scanned area: ~1 mm 2 . Step size: 1 mm. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 2. Temperature dependence of Young's modulus E (white background, B24 sample) and shear modulus G (yellow background, B23 sample) of the HfNbTaTiZr refractory high-entropy alloy. Eqs. (5) and (6) were fitted (red lines) to the experimental data and the fitting equations are shown next to the curves. For more details see text. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 3. Discontinuity in the Young's modulus. (left y-axis) Young's modulus and (right y-axis) damping coefficient of polycrystalline HfNbTaTiZr as a function of temperature. For details see text.

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 4. (a) Young's modulus E and (b) shear modulus G as a function of temperature for the polycrystalline HfNbTaTiZr high-entropy alloy (black lines) and for polycrystalline,Hf, Nb, Ta, Ti, and Zr pure metals with a BCC structure reported in the literature. Note that Hf, Ti, and Zr form a stable BCC structure at high temperatures where the HCP to BCC phase transformation temperatures are highlighted with red, green, and purple arrows, respectively (below these temperature, the BCC phase is not stable). Full lines are experimental data obtained for polycrystalline Nb and Ta. Empty symbols at 0 K are single crystalline data determined using first principle calculations or density functional theory which were converted to polycrystalline elastic moduli assuming the Voigt-Reuss-Hill average. Similarly experimental data obtained for single crystalline Nb and Ta were converted to polycrystalline elastic moduli, see blue and pink dashed lines. Dotted lines are guides for the eye. For more details, see text. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

figure.head: Table 3
figure.figDesc: Temperatures at which O, C, and N interstitials would cause a damping peak in Nb and Ta for an excitation frequency of ~7 kHz. These values were calculated using the Snoek relaxation parameters of Weller[49].

figure.head: Table 4
figure.figDesc: Elastic constants compiled from various sources for pure elements with a BCC structure including Hf, Nb, Ta, Ti, and Zr. These elastic constants were determined either theoretically by first principle calculations (FP) and density functional theory (DFT) or experimentally using resonance frequency techniques (RFT) or phonon dispersion (PD).

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: GL acknowledges funding from the German Research Foundation (Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft DFG) through the Priority Program SPP 2006 "Compositionally Complex Alloys -High Entropy Alloys" project LA 3607/3. JPC, LP and IG would like to acknowledge the French National Research Agency (ANR) for the support through the ANR 16-CE08-0027 "TURBO-AHEAD" program.
